By NIELS SUNDERMEYER
Due to a "discrepancy in election procedure" Freshman final elections earlier this week were invalidated by
the Student Council.
Council President Tony Salem cited "our responsibility to the Freshman Class" as the reason for its action
Tuesday after it was announced that the ballot box had —
been "tampered with" in the dormitory Monday night.
After lengthy discussion the Council moved to re-run the
elections yesterday and today.
Precipitating what proved to be one the Council's
most intense banterings of the
year was the report by one of
its members that he had been
present when "several upperclassmen" discovered the "unlocked" ballot box after the close
of the first day's voting Monday.

MEDICINE BALL—HOPKINS STYLE
Two intercollegiate ga-mes, two dances, and a series
of intramural contests will be the principal events of ODK
Fall Weekend this Friday and Saturday.
The Weekend is sponsored by Omicron Delta Kappa,
national leadership fraternity, "to foster school spirit and
to make everyone realize that he is a part of the athletic
and social activities at. Hopkins, "says Fall Weekend Chairman Stan Middleman.
Activities begin at one p.m. today when Class Day
activities pit Freshmen against Sophomores and Juniors
against Seniors in basketball,
football, volleyball, pushball and
tug-of-war to determine the
winning .class of each pair. Joe
Jeziorski and class officers who
are conducting Class Day, have
announced that teams with the
highest number of points will
alsO receive prizes.
A Dorm Rally, sponsored by
the Booster Club, will be held at
7 P.m. tonight. The Dormitory
Students Representative Council
will hold a mixer afterward from
8:30 to one in Levering Hall.
Varsity Soccer and Varsity
Football will meet traditional
rival Western Maryland Saturday; soccer at 11 a.m., football
at 2 p.m.
The Weekend will be brought
to a climax by the Pigskin Hop,
sponsored by the 'H' Club from
9 to one tomorrow in the Gymnasium. Johnny Paterson's Band
will play, featuring both dance
Music and dixieland.

JHU Engineers
Organize Society
For Top Students
An organizational meeting of
the Johns Hopkins Electrical
Engineering Honor Society was
held on November 6 with 20
juniors and seniors in attendance.
The society is working for
acceptance as a chapter of Eta
Kappa Nu, national honor society for electrical engineers. Dr.
William Huggins, Professor of
Electrical Engineering and one
of the three Hopkins faculty
members of Eta Kappa Nu, told
the group of the Greek-letter
society's accomplishments and
the advantages of membership.
Other faculty members are
Dr. William B. Kouwenhoven,
Professor Emeritus of Elecrical
Engineering, and Foster H.

Second 'Stormer
Offering Of Year
To Start Friday
"Rehearsals are coming along
very well," according to Dave
Hochberg, President of the
"Doctor's
for
Barnstormers,
Dilemma," the latest endeavor
for the campus dramatic group.
The well-known George Bernard Shaw play will run Friday
and Saturday evenings, December 6 and 7 in Shriver Hall with
free admission.
Mike Dale has been cast in the
male lead and the leading female
role is handled by Toni Riddleberger, in the Shaw spoof on the
medical profession. The entire
cast is composed of eleven men
and three women, a small cast
for a major 'Stormer production.
Set and scenery designs will
follow a simplified and modernistic pattern. There will be one
basic set with five variations in
the course of the five acts.
"We have had to switch a few
roles around," stated Hochberg,
"but the rehearsals are now at
full swing and the cast is coming
along. The play itself," continued the Barnstormer Prexy,
"ought to go ever very well. People generally like Shaw, and this
al farce should
.
particular medic
appeal to the students on campus. Everyone in the production
is doing well and we expect a
success."
"Doctor's Dilemma" will be the
second play presented by the
Barnstormers this year. The previous presentation, "Stalag 17,"
was staged by the freshmen in
October. One more production,
"Charlie's Aunt," is planned for
the spring.

"Not Interfering"
Admitting that Jie did not attempt to interfere, the Councilman said: "I did not feel that
they were trying to throw the
elections in any way .. • theyc
were only looking for something
to do. I could see that the individuals were only interested in
the progress of the election ...
and were merely counting the
presidential votes."
Asked why the ballot box was
left open, the Council member
reported that "there was no lock
on it."
,
Faced with the problem of possible protests and spread of false
rumors of the election's progress,
the Council debated changing
election dates. A protest was
heard that a new election would
be "too much work." Student
Council President Salem said: "I
don't think we should consider
the work involved or whether or
not the votes were changed in
favor of any candidate. This
whole matter will give the freshmen an unfavorable attitude toWard Hopkins and the Council
unless there is an honest election, and regardless of the fact
that no protest may be raised
I think we should act now and
cancel the election in progress."

Girinicks, Boynicks, Hopniks
The Interfraternity Board Fall
Formal Dance was "a success,"
according to in3 President Gil
Decker, who commented that the
drinking was "not in excess"
and that "everyone behaved
himself, except for one incident
when someone tried to take a
ladder to pull down the decorations."
Awarding of the Bowman
Trophy did not take place at the
dance "because the formal winner had not been tabulated,"
said Decker.

Decker also stated that he
thought there could have been
"more discretion in the announcement of engagements and
pinnings, most of which were
faked. In at least one circumstance it proved most embarrassing to the couple involved."

At the Applied Physics Laboratory (APL) of The
Johns Hopkins University you will be in the vanguard
of the science of guided missiles. APL has been recognized as a leader in this field since 1948, when we
completed successful field tests of TERRIER (now
in service use).
You will enjoy more freedom to use your initiative
and a larger measure of responsibility than is extended
recent graduates by most research and development
organizations. .
You might cOnduct experiments in every frequency
region; engage in transistor research; study frequency
modulation; electrical noise and interference phenomena; radar systems; servo-mechanisms -theory; or
pulse techniques. You might also be called upon to
help design and construct electro-mechanical computers or to develop magnetic-amplifier circuits.
You would work on advanced circuitry capable of
performing under unusual environmental conditions
in complex guided missile systems and be concerned
with the mating of functional components into complete systems.
Qualified candidates will be invited to visit our new
laboratory in Howard County, Maryland. Those selected will be given the opportunity of choosing their
own starting positions. Salaries compare favorably
with industrial organizations, and our fringe benefits
are excellent due to our affiliation with the University.
For detailed information ask your Placement Officer
for our new 30,page publication or write: Professional Staff Appointments.

The Violating Fraternity
Fraternity open rushing is concluded. Pledges are
cozily nested in their respective classes, and we now can
view those six strenuous weeks in retrospect.
This year's 'rush' was madder than any hatter and
as cutthroat as a Machiavellian state. It is evident that
the great amount of dirt which fraternities slung at one
another, that the flagrant violations of the rush rules and
of the "spirit" of clean rushing were due to a fault in the
IFB's rush rule clause which governs blacklisting.
Article 5, section 2 of the rushing rules states,
"(Freshmen's) participation in a violation, shall, at the
discretion of the Board, result in their blacklisting for one
year." "Blacklisting," as defined, means that the freshman shall be allowed to join no fraternity for one year.
The rigidity of the clause has defeated its own purpose. To state a hypothetical case, fraternities 'A' and
'IV both desire to pledge the same freshman, and 'A'
Commits a violation. 'B' will not submit the violation
to the Inter-fraternity Board, as a conviction will blacklist
that freshman from fraternity 'B,' as well as from 'A.'
Consequently fraternity 'B' resorts to the tactics of `A';
the result is a period of mutual mud slinging.
The solution is simple. The blacklisting clause should
be altered to read that participation in a violation shall
result in "their blacklisting for one year from the violating
fraternity." As it would limit that fraternity's competition, blacklist solely upon the guilty party would encourage one fraternity to turn in a violation.
If such a clause does not put the cork on rushing
violations, nothing will.

Spinning Wheels
In the closed community of Hopkins, we have an opportunity to practice democracy under almost ideal conditions.
But it has struck us that three of the most important
and influential governing bodies are operating very inefficiently. We are referring to the Student Council, the
Interfraternity Board and the Dormitory Students Representative Council.
The first impression we receive while watching these
bodies in action is that most of the time they are only
spinning their wheels. Many words are spent, much time
is consumed, but little is accomplished. Democracy may
require more discussion to solve a problem than other
forms of government, and with this we have no quarrel.
But much of the talk to which we refer is needless discussion, repetition of the same point not even disguised
in different words.
We suggest that the meetings will run much smoother
if the chairmen of each of these groups will read Robert's
Rules of Order and abide by them. Experience has shown
that a meeting cannot run smoothly, and thus democracy
is suppressed, by the chair dominating discussion.
We further suggest that more use be made of existing
committees. Not enough work is done in committees, and
when it is done, the report is hashed over to the extent
that the committee's work is all redone.
If these suggestions are carried out, we feel that
these three bodies may be able to fulfill their jobs as
student governing bodies. More complete and intelligent
pertinent discussion can take place which will lead to
.better decisions. Democracy can function and these organizations can make Hopkins student life richer by providing guidance.

Rosenberg

on a floor that was electrically

removed and replaced with a
metal tube to measure the
amount of water I drink?

Once upon a time at the University of Virginia there was
a coed named,oddly enough, Virginia University who was
handsome and kindly and intelligent and ingeniously constructed and majoring in psychology. Virginia went steady
with a young man on campus named, oddly enough,
Oddly Enough who was supple and fair and lithe and animated and majoring in phys ed.
Virginia and Oddly enjoyed a romance that was as
idyllic as a summer day, as placid as a millpond. Never
did they fight—never, never, never l—because Virginia,
who was majoring in psychology, did not believe in fighting. "Fighting," she often said, "settles nothing. The scientific way is to look calmly for the cause of the friction."
So whenever she and Oddly were on the verge of a
quarrel,she used to whip out a series of ink blot tests and
they would discover the true underlying cause of their
dispute and deal with it in an enlightened, dispassionate
manner. Then,the irritant removed, their romance would
resume its tranquil, serene, unruffled course.
After six months of this sedate liaison, Oddly was so
bored he could spit. He loved Virginia well enough, but
he also believed that people in love ought to fight now
and then."It opens the pores," he said."And besides, it's
so much fun making up afterwards."
But Virginia would not be provoked into a quarrel.
One night Oddly tried very hard. "Hey," he said to her,
"your hair looks like a bat's nest and your ears look like
last year's turnips and your face looks like a pan of worms
and as for your head, l've seen better heads on newel
posts."
"My goodness, we're. hostile tonight!" said Virginia
cheerfully and whipped 120 Rorschach cards out of her
reticule. "Come," she said, "let us examine your psychic
apparatus."

Career opportunities at Du Pont are
greater today than ever before because of the Company's continued
growth. In 1957, Du Pont's sales
were at the $2 billion level. Four new
plants were being built. New research
programs were being launched, and
new products were moving into the
production and marketing stages. All
of these developments tend to broaden
opportunities at Du Pont for the
young scientist and engineer.
ALL KINDS OF ENGINEERS
Students with chemical engineering
and chemistry degrees are needed, of
course. But the opportunities are
equally great for students majoring
in many other fields. And the type of
work for these men varies greatly.
Among other things:
Mechanical engineers work in re-

search and development as well as in
plant engineering and production
supervision.
Metallurgical engineers conduct
studies in metal fatigue and corrosion
and engage in fundamental research
into the nature and properties of
elemen ts.
Civil engineers have many assignments, including design and supervision of the construction of Du Pont
plants and laboratories.
Men studying for degrees in electrical, mining, petroleum, industrial and
many other specialized fields of engineering will find equally challenging
outlets for their talents at Du Pont.
If you're interested in finding full
scope for your ability, Du Pont offers
you plenty of opportunity.

Du Pont Training Tailored to Individual
Each of Du Pont's operating departments has its own training program
because each has special requirements. But both formal and informal
programs are tailored to the interests
and needs of the individual.
Generally, you go to work on an
assignment at once and start learning
right away. This headstart on responsibility is an important factor in your
progress. Based on your qualifications, you're given one segment of a
project to tickle almost immediately.

You learn quickly and informally in
consultation with your supervisor and
other engineers on the same project.
This training is supplemented by frequent meetings, seminars, studies of
plant operations and procedures.
And since Du Pont is interested in
the progress of the individual, your

performance is evaluated at regular
intervals by your supervisor. These
discussions bring out your strong and
weak points and together you work
out a program for improvement. This
training and evaluation continues
year after year as you advance in
the Company.
SEND FOR INFORMATION BOOKLET
Booklets on jobs at Du Pont are
yours for the asking. Subjects
include: mechanical, civil, metallurgical, chemical, electrical, instrumentation and industrial
engineers at Du Pont; atomic
energy, technical sales, research
and development. Name the subject that interests you in a letter
to Du Pont, 2494-B Nemours
Building, Wilmington 98, Del.

By STAN HANDMAKER
Sports Editor

With the appointment of Carl Hartman, a former
Johns Hopkins tennis captain, as coach of the net squad
for the coming year, the netmen can at least be assured
of tutoring, something they almost missed out on last
year. Now that things are progressing well with them
this year, chances look good for their getting adequate
equipment, including tennis balls.
Scheduling for wrestling for the 1958-1959 season
takes place next month, and Athletic Director Marshall
Turner has stated that he does not plan to schedule any
meets for Hopkins.
Turner bases this decision on past experience with
wrestling at Hopkins. Last year the members of the
varsity grappling squad numbered almost half of the
original turnout in the fall when the sport was dropped
from the Jays' intercollegiate program.
Of the thirty-five or forty that showed up at the organizational meeting of the team, Turner expects at least
three or four to be absent when practice begins Tuesday,
December 3.
He expects the squad's ranks to be depleted following
the Christmas vacation and again after mid-year finals.
After these three 'days of decision,' the size of the
roster generally remains constant.
Since he has had to cancel this year's and last year's
schedules, Turner does-not want to have to do the same
thing again.
A large squad at the end of this season and a big
turnout next fall would justify his scheduling meets for
the 1959-1960 season believes Turner.
However, if this is not the case, the best the wrestlers
can hope for is a possible schedule for this year's freshmen's senior year.
Since the wrestling program has been hampered by
a general lack of enthusiasm in the past, Turner cannot
be given full blame for the current situation.
Very few schools will risk scheduling a meet with
Hopkins, if the Jays cancel three out of four. Also if
Hopkins does not schedule any meets for a number of
years, the chances of getting former opponents to again
schedule them will be slim, as the schools will probably
have any open dates filled by then.
The situation is quite involved, and the only solution
appears to be the wrestlers' showing that they are justified
in asking for wrestling's 'reincarnation' by giving the
sport the necessary support.

and social activities at. Hopkins, "says Fall Weekend Chairman Stan Middleman.

rival Western Maryland Saturday; soccer at 11 a.m., football

The Violating Fraternity
Fraternity open rushing is concluded. Pledges are
cozily nested in their respective classes, and we now can
view those six strenuous weeks in retrospect.
This year's 'rush' was madder than any hatter and
as cutthroat as a Machiavellian state. It is evident that
the great amount of dirt which fraternities slung at one
another, that the flagrant violations of the rush rules and
of the "spirit" of clean rushing were due to a fault in the
IFB's rush rule clause which governs blacklisting.
Article 5, section 2 of the rushing rules states,
"(Freshmen's) participation in a violation, shall, at the
discretion of the Board, result in their blacklisting for one
year." "Blacklisting," as defined, means that the freshman shall be allowed to join no fraternity for one year.
The rigidity of the clause has defeated its own purpose. To state a hypothetical case, fraternities 'A' and
'IV both desire to pledge the same freshman, and 'A'
Commits a violation. 'B' will not submit the violation
to the Inter-fraternity Board, as a conviction will blacklist
that freshman from fraternity 'B,' as well as from 'A.'
Consequently fraternity 'B' resorts to the tactics of `A';
the result is a period of mutual mud slinging.
The solution is simple. The blacklisting clause should
be altered to read that participation in a violation shall
result in "their blacklisting for one year from the violating
fraternity." As it would limit that fraternity's competition, blacklist solely upon the guilty party would encourage one fraternity to turn in a violation.
If such a clause does not put the cork on rushing
violations, nothing will.

Spinning Wheels
In the closed community of Hopkins, we have an opportunity to practice democracy under almost ideal conditions.
But it has struck us that three of the most important
and influential governing bodies are operating very inefficiently. We are referring to the Student Council, the
Interfraternity Board and the Dormitory Students Representative Council.
The first impression we receive while watching these
bodies in action is that most of the time they are only
spinning their wheels. Many words are spent, much time
is consumed, but little is accomplished. Democracy may
require more discussion to solve a problem than other
forms of government, and with this we have no quarrel.
But much of the talk to which we refer is needless discussion, repetition of the same point not even disguised
in different words.
We suggest that the meetings will run much smoother
if the chairmen of each of these groups will read Robert's
Rules of Order and abide by them. Experience has shown
that a meeting cannot run smoothly, and thus democracy
is suppressed, by the chair dominating discussion.
We further suggest that more use be made of existing
committees. Not enough work is done in committees, and
when it is done, the report is hashed over to the extent
that the committee's work is all redone.
If these suggestions are carried out, we feel that
these three bodies may be able to fulfill their jobs as
student governing bodies. More complete and intelligent
pertinent discussion can take place which will lead to
.better decisions. Democracy can function and these organizations can make Hopkins student life richer by providing guidance.

Rosenberg

Once upon a time at the University of Virginia there was
a coed named,oddly enough, Virginia University who was
handsome and kindly and intelligent and ingeniously constructed and majoring in psychology. Virginia went steady
with a young man on campus named, oddly enough,
Oddly Enough who was supple and fair and lithe and animated and majoring in phys ed.
Virginia and Oddly enjoyed a romance that was as
idyllic as a summer day, as placid as a millpond. Never
did they fight—never, never, never l—because Virginia,
who was majoring in psychology, did not believe in fighting. "Fighting," she often said, "settles nothing. The scientific way is to look calmly for the cause of the friction."
So whenever she and Oddly were on the verge of a
quarrel,she used to whip out a series of ink blot tests and
they would discover the true underlying cause of their
dispute and deal with it in an enlightened, dispassionate
manner. Then,the irritant removed, their romance would
resume its tranquil, serene, unruffled course.
After six months of this sedate liaison, Oddly was so
bored he could spit. He loved Virginia well enough, but
he also believed that people in love ought to fight now
and then."It opens the pores," he said."And besides, it's
so much fun making up afterwards."
But Virginia would not be provoked into a quarrel.
One night Oddly tried very hard. "Hey," he said to her,

last year's turnips and your face looks like a pan of worms
and as for your head, l've seen better heads on newel
posts."
"My goodness, we're. hostile tonight!" said Virginia
cheerfully and whipped 120 Rorschach cards out of her
reticule. "Come," she said, "let us examine your psychic
apparatus."

Career opportunities at Du Pont are
greater today than ever before because of the Company's continued
growth. In 1957, Du Pont's sales
were at the $2 billion level. Four new
plants were being built. New research
programs were being launched, and
new products were moving into the
production and marketing stages. All
of these developments tend to broaden
opportunities at Du Pont for the
young scientist and engineer.
ALL KINDS OF ENGINEERS
Students with chemical engineering
and chemistry degrees are needed, of
course. But the opportunities are
equally great for students majoring
in many other fields. And the type of
work for these men varies greatly.
Among other things:
Mechanical engineers work in re-

search and development as well as in
plant engineering and production
supervision.
Metallurgical engineers conduct
studies in metal fatigue and corrosion
and engage in fundamental research
into the nature and properties of
elemen ts.
Civil engineers have many assignments, including design and supervision of the construction of Du Pont
plants and laboratories.
Men studying for degrees in electrical, mining, petroleum, industrial and
many other specialized fields of engineering will find equally challenging
outlets for their talents at Du Pont.
If you're interested in finding full
scope for your ability, Du Pont offers
you plenty of opportunity.

Du Pont Training Tailored to Individual
Each of Du Pont's operating departments has its own training program
because each has special requirements. But both formal and informal
programs are tailored to the interests
and needs of the individual.
Generally, you go to work on an
assignment at once and start learning
right away. This headstart on responsibility is an important factor in your
progress. Based on your qualifications, you're given one segment of a
project to tickle almost immediately.

You learn quickly and informally in
consultation with your supervisor and
other engineers on the same project.
This training is supplemented by frequent meetings, seminars, studies of
plant operations and procedures.
And since Du Pont is interested in
the progress of the individual, your

performance is evaluated at regular
intervals by your supervisor. These
discussions bring out your strong and
weak points and together you work
out a program for improvement. This
training and evaluation continues
year after year as you advance in
the Company.

Booklets on jobs at Du Pont are
yours for the asking. Subjects
include: mechanical, civil, metallurgical, chemical, electrical, instrumentation and industrial
engineers at Du Pont; atomic
energy, technical sales, research
and development. Name the subject that interests you in a letter
to Du Pont, 2494-B Nemours
Building, Wilmington 98, Del.

By STAN HANDMAKER
Sports Editor

With the appointment of Carl Hartman, a former
Johns Hopkins tennis captain, as coach of the net squad
for the coming year, the netmen can at least be assured
of tutoring, something they almost missed out on last
year. Now that things are progressing well with them
this year, chances look good for their getting adequate
equipment, including tennis balls.
Scheduling for wrestling for the 1958-1959 season
takes place next month, and Athletic Director Marshall
Turner has stated that he does not plan to schedule any
meets for Hopkins.
Turner bases this decision on past experience with
wrestling at Hopkins. Last year the members of the
varsity grappling squad numbered almost half of the
original turnout in the fall when the sport was dropped
from the Jays' intercollegiate program.
Of the thirty-five or forty that showed up at the organizational meeting of the team, Turner expects at least
three or four to be absent when practice begins Tuesday,
December 3.
He expects the squad's ranks to be depleted following
the Christmas vacation and again after mid-year finals.
After these three 'days of decision,' the size of the
roster generally remains constant.
Since he has had to cancel this year's and last year's
schedules, Turner does-not want to have to do the same
thing again.
A large squad at the end of this season and a big
turnout next fall would justify his scheduling meets for
the 1959-1960 season believes Turner.
However, if this is not the case, the best the wrestlers
can hope for is a possible schedule for this year's freshmen's senior year.
Since the wrestling program has been hampered by
a general lack of enthusiasm in the past, Turner cannot
be given full blame for the current situation.
Very few schools will risk scheduling a meet with
Hopkins, if the Jays cancel three out of four. Also if
Hopkins does not schedule any meets for a number of
years, the chances of getting former opponents to again
schedule them will be slim, as the schools will probably
have any open dates filled by then.
The situation is quite involved, and the only solution
appears to be the wrestlers' showing that they are justified
in asking for wrestling's 'reincarnation' by giving the
sport the necessary support.

Former Captain

It's Homecoming tomorrow as
the Hopkins varsity gridders return to Homewood to take on
traditional rival Western Maryland at 2:00 p.m.
This is the 36th renewal in an
intra-state series which dates
back to 1894.
Hopkins has
blanked Western Maryland the
past two years running.
The contest is rated a toss-up,
although Hopkins sports a 2-2-2
mark against a 1-5-1 seasonal
log for the Green Terrros. The
teams are tied at 0-1-1 in Mason-Dixon Conference action.
Against mutual opponents Randolph-Macon, Hampden-Sydney.
and Franklin and Marshall, both
teams have lost two and tied
one.
Fewster Respects Terrors
Hopkins Football coach Wilson Fewster credits Western
Maryland with playing some excellent football this season, and
attributes the Terrors' meager
(Cnntinued on Page 11

Frosh Pitchmen
Lose To Plebes
In Final Contest
The freshman soccer team
closed their season losing to the
Navy plebes at Annapolis last
Friday afternoon, by a final
score of three to one, the only
Hopkins tally being scor:. • by
Bob Dickenson in the second
half.
The trosh soccermen ended
the season with a two wins,
two loses, and one tie. The Blue
Jays beat the Towson Junior
Varsity once and tied them 2-2
in their second encounter. They
also beat Park School and lost
to Calvert Hall and the Navy
Plebes.
Coach George Whitlock, a
graduate student at the University, was satisfied with the
team's play during the season.
There were many outstanding
players on the team, he indicated. He mentioned especially
Don Evenson, Don Schuerholz,
Jim Payne, Ron Wozniak and
Joe Zeuch.
There were some players,
Whitlock indicated, who might
possibly be in a position to help
the varsity soccer team for next
year's season.

BIA
Phi Sig beat Phi Gam to take
the fraternity football championship.
In fraternity golf A. E. Pi, who
downed D. U., will meet Beta in
the semi-finals.
Phi Sigma will meet A. D. in
the finals of fraternity tennis.
Tony Taubert took the independent golf title by forfeit.
Independent tennis is not yet
in the semi-finals.
The Nads will meet the Rowland Ghosts for the independent
football championship.
Phi Gam won the cross country team trophy with Jim McAllister of D. U. taking the individual trophy.
